children.text: This section of the dwelling has a gap that not been properly sealed to the external wall, floor or roof cavities, which will allow air movement and reduce the energy efficiency of this home.
Part 3.12.3 Building Sealing of the NCCâ€™s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires in section 3.12.3.5 that

'Ceilings, walls, floors and any opening such as a window frame, door frame, roof light frame or the like must be constructed to minimise air leakage when forming part of the external fabric of a conditioned space, or a habitable room' .
This section of the BCA also includes a paragraph on how it should be constructed to avoid air leakage in section 3.12.3.5

'Construction must be enclosed by internal lining systems that are close fitting at ceiling, wall and floor junctions; or sealed at junctions and penetrations with close-fitting architrave, skirting or cornice; or expanding foam, rubber compressive strip, caulking or the like' .
These building air gaps must be sealed in all areas in accordance with the building code requirements above.
